{{Infobox aviator | name = Sharifah Czarena | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | full_name = | birth_name = | birth_date = <!-- {{Birth date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | birth_place = | nationality = Bruneian | education = | spouse = | relatives = | known_for = First female Captain from Brunei | first_flight_date = | first_flight_aircraft = | famous_flights = | license_date = | license_place = | rank = Captain | awards = | memorials = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | child = | module = }}
'''Sharifah Czarena''' is a [[Brunei]]an pilot, who was the first woman from Brunei to captain a commercial airliner. She was initially seconded to [[Loganair]], where she flew the [[Saab 340]]. Since flying for [[Royal Brunei Airlines]], she has flown [[Boeing 767]]s and [[Boeing 787 Dreamliner]]s.
==Career== Sharifah Czarena trained as a pilot cadet in 2003, taking her lessons at the Cabair Flying School, [[Cranfield]].<ref name="inspire">{{cite web|title=Captain Sharifah Czarena|url=https://yesinspire.com/captain-sharifah-czarena/|publisher=Inspire|accessdate=9 November 2017}}</ref> After graduating in 2004, she was seconded from [[Royal Brunei Airlines]] to Scottish carrier [[Loganair]] for two years, flying the [[Saab 340]].<ref name="inspire"/><ref name="travel">{{cite news|title=A day in the life: Captain Sharifah Czarena|url=http://www.travelweekly.co.uk/articles/63466/a-day-in-the-life-captain-sharifah-czarena|accessdate=9 November 2017|work=Travel Weekly|date=12 October 2016}}</ref> On her return to Royal Brunei Airlines, she flew the [[Boeing 767]] as a First Officer.<ref name="inspire"/>
Czarena was promoted to Senior First Officer in 2007, and to Captain in 2012.<ref name="inspire"/> She was the first woman from Brunei to become the captain of a commercial airliner.<ref name=nyt>{{cite news|title=First all-women flight crew from Brunei lands in country where women can’t drive|url=http://nytlive.nytimes.com/womenintheworld/2016/03/15/first-all-women-flight-crew-from-brunei-lands-in-country-where-women-cant-drive/|accessdate=9 November 2017|work=New York Times|date=15 March 2016}}</ref> At the time, she said "Being a pilot, people normally see it as being a male dominant occupation. As a woman, a Bruneian woman, it is such a great achievement. It’s really showing the younger generation or the girls especially that whatever they dream of, they can achieve it."<ref>{{cite news|last1=O'Shea|first1=Ronan J.|title=Southwest Airlines celebrates first all-female flight crew|url=https://www.msn.com/en-gb/lifestyle/travel/southwest-airlines-celebrates-first-all-female-flight-crew/ar-AAtKSRG|accessdate=9 November 2017|work=The Independent|date=23 October 2017}}</ref>
In 2016, she made history as the Captain of the first all female flight crew to land in [[Jeddah]], [[Saudi Arabia]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sandhu|first1=Serina|title=Royal Brunei Airlines' first all-female pilot crew lands plane in Saudi Arabia - where women are not allowed to drive|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/royal-brunei-airlines-first-all-female-flight-deck-crew-lands-plane-in-saudi-arabia-where-women-are-a6931726.html|accessdate=9 November 2017|work=The Independent|date=15 March 2016}}</ref> a country at which time did not allow women to get [[driving licence]]s. The flight was timed to celebrate Brunei's National Day.<ref>{{cite news|title=Saudi Arabia: All female Brunei crew in historic flight|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-35816887|accessdate=9 November 2017|work=BBC News|date=15 March 2016}}</ref> Alongside her in the [[Boeing 787 Dreamliner]] were Senior First Officers Dk Nadiah Pg Khashiem and [[Sariana Nordin]].<ref name=nyt/>
